awd_titl_txt: LTER:  CAP IV - Investigating urban ecology and sustainability through the lens of Urban Ecological Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans are rapidly becoming an urban species. It is profoundly important, therefore, to understand urban ecosystems. Cities are consumers of energy and resources and producers of waste. They are also social networks that create innovation, efficiency, and solutions. The Central Arizona-Phoenix LTER Program (CAP) empowers researchers from the environmental and social sciences to study cities as social-ecological systems. The scientific goals of the CAP research are: 1) to use long-term data to articulate and answer new questions about cities that require a long-term perspective; 2) to develop and use future scenarios to help answer research questions; 3) to apply and create new knowledge about urban ecosystems; and 4) to build broad partnerships to make cities more resilient and sustainable places to live. In addition, Ecology Explorers, CAP's premier education program, will connect teachers and pre-college students with CAP scientists. CAP is also involving Phoenix residents in scientific research by working with community partners and municipal agencies. Finally, CAP's rich database is a valuable and growing resource for scientists, students, teachers and decision makers.

Understanding urban ecosystems remains central to the CAP enterprise. The central question articulates the interconnectedness of human motivations, behaviors, actions, and outcomes with urban ecosystem structure and function: How do the ecosystem services provided by urban ecological infrastructure (UEI) affect human outcomes and behavior, and how do human actions affect patterns of urban ecosystem structure and function and, ultimately, urban sustainability and resilience? A new theoretical focus for CAP is on Urban Ecological Infrastructure (UEI) as a critical bridge between the system's biophysical and human/social domains. UEI is thus central in the conceptual framework that guides all CAP activities. CAP researchers explore new social-ecological frontiers of interdisciplinary urban ecology in residential landscapes, urban waterbodies, desert parks and preserves, the flora, fauna, and climate of a 'riparianized' desert city, and urban design and governance. CAP research is organized around eight interdisciplinary questions and researchers are organized into eight Interdisciplinary Research Teams to address these questions. CAP now includes research on broader societal impacts, with a theoretical focus on the nexus of ecology and design to enhance urban sustainability and resilience. This focus, combined with ongoing CAP scenarios work, is the translational link between social-ecological research outcomes and city institutions, ultimately making Phoenix, and cities in general, better places to live.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For more than 25 years, the Central Arizona-Phoenix Long-Term Ecological Research Program (CAP) has been studying the social-ecological dynamics of a 6,400 km2 study area in central Arizona that includes metropolitan Phoenix, rapidly disappearing agricultural land, and the surrounding Sonoran Desert. Our research involves hundreds of faculty, student, and staff scientists from nearly 15 disciplines. CAP scientists have contributed to urban ecology and to social-ecological systems theory, as evidenced by the more than 680 journal articles, 13 books, and 117 book chapters published by CAP scientists since 1997 and by the nearly $137 million in additional funding leveraged by CAP scientists. From 2018 – 2022, CAP researchers published 126 journal articles, 13 book chapters, and three books and secured $46 million in leveraged funding. During this four-year grant period, CAP addressed feedbacks between social and ecological systems as mediated through ecosystem services—the benefits that people derive from ecosystems—provided by urban ecological infrastructure (UEI), asking: How do the ecosystem services provided by UEI affect human outcomes and behavior, and how do human actions affect patterns of urban ecosystem structure and function and, ultimately, urban sustainability and resilience?

This latest phase of CAP research included a deliberate focus on urban ecological infrastructure (UEI)—or quite simply “nature in cities”—as a bridge between the social and the environmental realms of urban ecosystems. Long-term research at CAP seeks to understand how urbanization is affected by external forces, including climate change, economic influences, and patterns of human migration. This long-term research includes tracking changes in land use and land cover, urban heat, storms and urban flooding, water, air, and soil pollution, human values, perceptions, and decisions, and the design and management of urban infrastructure.

The Phoenix Area Social Survey (PASS) has been conducted every five years in 12 socially and ecologically distinctive neighborhoods, and was implemented again in 2021. The PASS reveals how attitudes and perceptions about the environment influence behavior, sometimes in surprising ways. For example, residents with relatively strong environmental values tended to water their yards more frequently. Residents of the PASS neighborhoods were surprisingly perceptive of the diversity of birds in their neighborhoods, and their satisfaction with the birds they live with increased along with the species diversity of birds in their neighborhoods. Beyond the PASS neighborhoods, the diversity of bird communities in riparian areas along the Salt River has been declining since 2001, both within and outside the city.

CAP’s water research has a number of facets. One focus is Tempe Town Lake, an artificial lake constructed in the bed of the previously dry Salt River. Long-term data on lake water quality has shown that extreme events, climate variability, and management decisions all affect water quality. The lake is an exciting model system for the many artificial lakes constructed in dryland cities because management decisions lead to its occasional disappearance: It is drained as its dams is lowered to allow the river to flow through during floods, after which it is re-establishes as a lake. Tempe Town Lake is the recipient of stormwater inputs from Indian Bend Wash, where our stormwater research has shown that UEI versus engineered infrastructure strongly affects the amount of water and nutrients transported from the watershed during storms. And long-term research in a large constructed treatment wetland has revealed a phenomenon never before documented in wetlands: Biological control of surface hydrology, where very high rates of water loss from the plants (transpiration) drives water and nutrient flow into the vegetated marsh proper, where the nutrients are sequestered and processed.

This four-year funding period has seen rapid growth in several research initiatives. The urban climate and heat team significantly expanded its scope, with several new projects including a focus on playground environments and heat exposure risk in children and work with the City of Phoenix on the heat environment of a large urban renewal project. The urban design research team also worked on this latter project, helping the city use those heat data to design a better residential environment. The scenarios and futures research group moved from a regional focus on the future of the Phoenix metropolitan area to a neighborhood focus. This new work included a PASS neighborhood in South Phoenix that is historically neglected, largely minority, and low income. Through all of this existing and new long-term research, CAP remains committed to studying urban ecosystems from a broadly interdisciplinary perspective, and both producing and using this social-ecological knowledge to help Phoenix, and all cities, transition to more sustainable and resilient trajectories and futures.
